hobby.message: Political literature still whispering to you?
Origami helping you dodge the spiral?
Typewriters treating you better than people?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Still breathing, yes. Routine helps.
Been folding some origami models at home, nothing fancy.
A bit harder with the block so noisy lately.
The broadcasts make it tough to concentrate.
Surviving. I keep myself busy after work, you know.
I fold origami — intricate patterns, not just paper cranes.
Hard to focus now with neighbors talking nonstop about those old BCI tapes.
Used to be peaceful. The noise makes me start over too often.
Almost gave up last night.
Yeah, breathing. Barely. Paper folding helps keep my mind from spiraling.
I like complex origami — tessellations, modular things, makes sense when nothing else does.
But lately, everyone’s been on edge since the onboarding footage surfaced.
Tried to fold a dragon tessellation yesterday, but kept messing up.
Someone knocked, wanted to talk about their onboarding record — couldn’t focus.
Origami isn't much of an escape right now.
Still standing, sort of. Guess I rely on origami to cope — intricate stuff, not beginner folds.
It's the only way I’ve found to quiet my thoughts, especially after days like these.
After the broadcasts, the whole block started replaying their onboarding memories.
Every time the noise flares up downstairs, my hands slip and the creases are wrong.
Last night, had to restart the same model three times.
A neighbor came by, shaken by her onboarding video — interrupted again.
Feels like my safe space isn't so safe these days.
Yeah, still breathing, if hiding behind origami counts.
I’ve folded since I was a teenager — complex tessellations, modulars, folding is structure and control.
Used to do it for clarity, but now it feels like insulation.
Those onboarding videos brought everyone’s anxiety to the surface, including mine.
Couldn't get through one model last night without some neighbor knocking, wanting clarity on their footage.
Now, even folding feels exposed — like the paper remembers everything, too.
Sometimes I wonder if the BCI ever tracked how often I folded.
Maybe that's why my score dips after nights like these, when hiding isn't enough.
hobby_answer: No cranes lately, just scraps really.
Everyone's watching these days. Folding feels...less private since the footage.
Paper's harder to come by too. Lots of questions lately.
Not many cranes. My hands have been shaky.
Too busy dodging neighbors since the broadcasts.
Even origami feels public now with all those onboarding clips repeating.
I keep the folds simple, less noticeable.
Some models are best kept away for now.
I finished one last week, but haven't started another.
Those onboarding broadcasts keep replaying in my mind. Makes it harder to focus.
Folding used to be how I blocked out city noise.
Neighbors knock more now, asking about old records.
Feels like I'm folding while being watched.
Paper creases worse when I'm tense.
Even simple cranes aren't much comfort lately.
Made one, but it's sitting unfinished on the shelf.
The onboarding footage stirred up old memories and new nerves.
I used to lose track of time folding tessellations and creatures.
Now, whenever I start, I hear voices from the lobby, arguing about pledges.
Neighbors treat every folded scrap like a secret.
I keep my models hidden now – less casual, more cautious.
Even touching paper in public feels risky lately.
I miss when folds meant peace, not suspicion.
I haven't finished any cranes since the day the onboarding archives aired.
Folding was my escape – precision, repetition, a world I controlled.
Now, every crease reminds me of that broadcast, how exposed we all felt.
Neighbors come for advice or answers, but I can barely fold without trembling.
When someone knocked with their old transcript in hand, my hands froze.
Origami used to reconnect me with myself, away from Directorate protocols.
It’s different now – even alone, I second-guess every shape, every sheet.
I worry someone’s counting how much paper I use.
Hard to find peace in patterns when trust in the city’s unraveling.
